intro: Rubus affinis var. briggsianus, commonly known as the California blackberry, is a variant of the blackberry plant native to the western United States. It is a deciduous shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters, featuring thorny stems and compound leaves with three to five leaflets. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers in the spring, which are followed by edible berries that ripen to a dark purple or black color in late summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and mountainous regions, where it plays a role in local ecosystems.
